what: Lets see the package in action
title: How to connect to motherduck
text: creating duckdb database, three options -memory based instance exists local computer file based instance exists local computer cloud-based instance motherduck create options 1 2 can simply use either duckdb duckplyr packages. use option 3, need create motherudck account generate access token. created, save access token R enviorment usethis::edit_r_environ(). recommend using MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN variable name. completed, can simply use connect_to_motherduck() function pass token variable name optional configuration options. Whats difference Motherduck Duckdb? Duckdb database can deploy run either temporary permanently computer. run via local computer, available computer Motherduck cloud based deployment duckdb means can save data cloud access locally core functions package work motherduck duckdb database question want data access locally computer want able access remotely via cloud return connection print statement indicating connection status. time can validate connection status validate_md_connection_status() create motherduck account access token? Go motherduck create account, free options available Go user name top right, click settings click access tokens Click create token name token copy token code need token access account want access via R simplest way save access code variable r environment Simply leverage usethis function edit_r_environ() set access code variable save – one time activity check correctly saved variable can use Sys.getenv(“var_name”) “var_name” named assigned access token Going forward, want access token don’t need re-type access token, simply remember variable name First need motherduck account, free paid tiers ’ve created account, simply, go settings click ‘Access Tokens’ ‘Integrations’ Keep secure safe lets connect online database read write data Open R use usethis::edit_r_environ() function put motherduck token variable enviornment profile MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN=‘tokenID’ can use connect_to_motherduck("MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN") use DBI library create connection mother duck instance connecting motherduck number configuration options available, can reference via motherduck::db_config pull list options default values change , simply edit configuration options want pass list argument connect_to_motherduck() duckdb() connecting locally can see full list duckdb configuration options alternatively can use list_settings() see current configuration options. 1 Access default configuration options via built list 2 change options want, ensure leverage duckdb syntax 3 pass modtified list config option function time can see configuration arguments connection motherduck::list_settings(). Congratulations, ’ve set connected motherduck database R! Please see {motherduck} package website see additional documentation use functions motherduck
code: con_md <- connect_to_motherduck("MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN") validate_md_connection_status(con_md) 1config <- config_db   2config$allow_community_extensions <- "true"  3con_md <- connect_to_motherduck("MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN",config = config) list_setting(con_md)

title: How to load data into Motherduck
text: get use package, lets quickly review three things need load data database: Database name (Catalog Name) object hold schemas, tables views Different databases naming convention, motherduck, called Catalog Schema name fancy name location classifies organizes tables, functions, procedures, etc Table view name name actual table view holds data Table can physical table data persists whereas view stored procedures queries underlying tables needed save reference data, need either fully qualify name database_name.schema_name.table_name need “” database schema reference table name. uploaded data without creating table schema first duckdb assign “temp” “main” default names database schema respectively. Note 1: Teminology: Duckdb vs. Motherduck technically correct explanation; motherduck cloud based deployment duckdb can multiple databases, control access / permissions, scale compute / storage needed Duckdb essentially single database instance local computer can save database file create memory. write ups, tend use duckdb & motherduck interchangeably however functions work motherduck database still work duckdb database. using local duckdb database can leave database argument blank.

Now knwo navigate various databaes, lets finally load data somee existing data new database schema. create_table() function create new database / schema save load data table. 1 Pass data function 2 List motherduck connection 3 database name (either new existing) 4 schema name (either new existing) 5 table name 6 Either overwrite append data Notice don’t assign object anything, just silently writes data database prints message confirming performed actions well summary catalogs, schemas, tables shares haves access validate data database, can following: can validate successfully saved table database running list_all_tables(). want access motherduck data, can simply leverage dplyr::tbl() DBI::dbGetQuery() functions motherduck connection pull data.

what: Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
title: Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
text: Moves one tables existing schema new (target) schema using ALTER TABLE ... SET SCHEMA. target schema exist, created first.

title: Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
text: .con valid DBI connection (DuckDB / MotherDuck). from_table_names Character vector table names move. new_schema Target schema name (tables moved).

title: Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
text: Invisibly returns character vector fully-qualified table names moved. Side effects: creates new_schema needed alters table schemas.

title: Move Tables from One Schema to Another — alter_table_schema
text: Ensures new_schema exists (CREATE SCHEMA EXISTS). table table_names, runs: ALTER TABLE old_schema.table SET SCHEMA new_schema. Table schema identifiers safely quoted glue::glue_sql().

what: Change Active Database and Schema — cd
title: Change Active Database and Schema — cd
text: Switches active database (optionally) schema valid DuckDB MotherDuck connection. function validates target database schema executing USE command provides user feedback via CLI messages.

title: Change Active Database and Schema — cd
Change Active Database and Schema — cd
text: .con valid DBI connection (DuckDB / MotherDuck). database_name character string specifying database switch . Must one available databases returned list_all_databases(). schema_name (Optional) character string specifying schema switch within given database. Must one available schemas returned list_current_schemas().

title: Change Active Database and Schema — cd
text: Invisibly returns message summarizing new connection context. Side effects include printing CLI headers showing current user database context.

title: Change Active Database and Schema — cd
text: cd() function analogous "change directory" command file system, database contexts. updates currently active database (optionally schema) given connection. target database schema exist, function aborts descriptive CLI error message.

what: Database, Schema, and Table Creator — cli_create_obj

text: function creates inserts data specified database, schema, table. database, schema, table provided, function attempts use current database, schema, table. first checks provided database, schema, table exists, either creates new one inserts existing one, based given parameters. generates action report indicating status operation, whether new database, schema, table created whether existing ones used.

Used describe whether existing table updated (e.g., "insert" "update").

what: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings
title: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings
text: Updates MotherDuck user's configuration settings, including token type, instance size, flock size. function uses MotherDuck REST API apply changes specified user.

title: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings
code: configure_md_user_settings(   user_name,   motherduck_token = "MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN",   token_type = "read_write",   instance_size = "pulse",   flock_size = 0 )

title: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings
text: user_name Character. username MotherDuck user configure. motherduck_token Character. admin user's MotherDuck token environment variable name (default: "MOTHERDUCK_TOKEN"). token_type Character. type access token user; must "read_write" "read_scaling" (default: "read_write"). instance_size Character. instance size user; must one "pulse", "standard", "jumbo", "mega", "giga" (default: "pulse"). flock_size Numeric. flock size user; must whole number 0 60 (default: 0).

title: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings
text: tibble containing API response, including updated settings user.

title: Configure a MotherDuck user's settings — configure_md_user_settings

title: Read a CSV file into a DuckDB/MotherDuck table — read_csv
text: .con valid DBI connection (DuckDB / MotherDuck). to_database_name Target database name (new existing) to_schema_name Target schema name  (new existing) to_table_name Target table name create  (new existing) file_path Path Excel file (.xlsx) header Logical; TRUE, first row header all_varchar Logical; coerce columns VARCHAR sample_size Numeric; number rows used type inference names Character vector; optional column names assign instead reading file types Named unnamed character vector; column types (named preferred, unnamed paired names) skip Integer; number rows skip beginning file union_by_name Logical; union multiple CSVs column name normalize_names Logical; normalize column names (lowercase, replace spaces) allow_quoted_nulls Logical; treat "NULL" quotes NULL ignore_errors Logical; continue row parse errors write_type Character; either "overwrite" "append", controls table creation behavior ... Additional arguments passed read_csv_auto() format listed duckdb documentation (optional)

title: Validate Installed MotherDuck/DuckDB Extensions — validate_extension_install_status

title: Validate Installed MotherDuck/DuckDB Extensions — validate_extension_install_status
text: validate_extension_install_status() function validates current connection checks requested extensions installed. produces detailed CLI report showing extensions installed, installed, missing. function can return different outputs based return_type argument: "msg": prints CLI report extension statuses. "ext": returns list containing success_ext (installed) fail_ext (installed). "arg": returns logical value indicating whether requested extensions installed.

title: Validate Installed MotherDuck/DuckDB Extensions — validate_extension_install_status
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ con <- DBI::dbConnect(duckdb::duckdb())  # Print CLI report validate_extension_install_status(con, extension_names = c("arrow", "excel"), return_type = "msg")  # Return a list of installed and failed extensions validate_extension_install_status(con, extension_names = c("arrow", "excel"), return_type = "ext")  # Return logical indicating if all requested extensions are installed validate_extension_install_status(con, extension_names = c("arrow", "excel"), return_type = "arg") } # }
